description: A traditional Ugandan-style stew made from fresh cassava leaves cooked until tender and enriched with groundnuts (peanut paste) or peanut butter, aromatics, and optional smoked fish or meat. Served with posho, rice, or matoke.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Cassava leaves are a common leafy green used across Uganda. Preparing them into a rich stew with groundnuts is a classic home-cooked dish served at family meals and special occasions.

ingredients.item: fresh cassava leaves, washed and finely chopped

utensils: mortar and pestle or blender (optional for grinding leaves/paste)

steps.instruction: Wash cassava leaves thoroughly. Remove tough stems and finely chop the leaves. If leaves are fibrous, pound lightly in a mortar or pulse briefly in a blender with a little water to help soften.
Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Sauté chopped onion until translucent, then add garlic and cook 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until they soften and form a loose sauce (4–6 minutes).

Stir in the chopped/pounded cassava leaves. Add water or stock to cover and bring to a gentle boil. Reduce heat and simmer, covered, for 40–60 minutes until leaves are tender. Stir occasionally and add more water if needed.

In a small bowl, mix the peanut butter with a little warm water to make a smooth paste. Add the groundnut paste to the pot and stir well to combine. Simmer another 10–15 minutes to thicken and allow flavors to meld.
Add smoked fish or dried fish if using, and season with salt, black pepper, and chopped chili to taste. Adjust consistency with water or stock; cook 5 more minutes.
Serve hot with posho, rice, matoke, or chapati. Garnish with a drizzle of oil or extra groundnuts if desired.

serving_suggestions: Serve alongside posho (maize porridge), rice, matoke, or chapati. Pairs well with grilled or stewed meats and a fresh salad.
